That's not entirely accurate. Low-wage service sector jobs are projected to expand, but so are the kind of high-end jobs you need a college degree for. Manufacturing has gone away, but that was never really a job for those with college degrees, it was a job for those with high school degrees. And also, that projection is under the status quo. There's no reason to expect that industries dependent on college-educated workers wouldn't expand under the 10% increase in degrees hypothesized in the article.

The number of professionals in the labor market now would have been unthinkable twenty, thirty, a hundred years ago. There's no reason it couldn't expand again, unless the robotics alarmists are right and it really is the end of work. And if that's the case, who cares what we do about anything?

J.C.: All your listing of superlatives doesn't help Climate Sensitivity converge, nor does it address the growing divergence between models and reality.

LA Times: Climate Models Don't Over-Predict Warming, Study Shows
http://www.latimes.com/science/sciencenow/la-sci-sn-climate-models-predi...

"'Cherry picking" the most recent 15-year interval to refute climate change modeling is misleading and obscures the long-term agreement between the models and measurements, according to study co-author Piers Forster, an atmospheric physicist from the University of Leeds, England.

A study that combined 114 possible 15-year trends since 1900 found that there was nothing statistically biased in the ways model-generated data differed from actual measurements of global mean surface temperatures...

For every start year after 1915, the modeled 62-year trends show too little warming, the study found...

Nine of the 10 warmest years on record have occurred since 2002, according to NOAA."
Kurts: I much enjoyed your haughty claim that you preferred to read the IPCC reports, given your history. thanks.

For a brief moment at the end of their chat, our host dared venture into a hard question: despite three and a half decades and billions of dollars spent, the "accepted range" for climate sensitivity hasn't been reduced since Charney (1979) 1.5 - 3.0 deg. C per doubling of CO2. Odd, that.

His guest then proclaimed, but "we're more certain now than we were back then!" (paraphrasing). Oooooo.... Kaaaaay.

Upon which our host went silent. I suppose he didn't wish to cause a fuss; after all, nobody from the audience seemed to care.

Strange, too, how the consensus Position of IPCC AR5 elected to NOT offer a "best estimate" for Climate Sensitivity, in a break from tradition. This wouldn't have anything to do with the recent research lowering estimates for C.S., would it?

How many scientific endeavors show such poor progress after spending billions? Should we not ask why? Could it be that some key assumptions are flawed?

I don't see any reason why this should be so, and I've never heard any psychologist maintain that it is so. Probably the ones you hear about are mostly extroverts who don't suffer from depression. That enables them to make more of a mark on the world more easily.

----As someone who has battled depression (more than once), I would wager that "depression" was the least of Mr. Lubitz's problems. A person who could calmly reprogram an airplane to crash into the mountains, while for ten minutes, 150 people are screaming in terror, is not "depressed." That man is a sociopath.....

And then there is utter selfishness, consuming anger at his employer, and evil.  He wasn't so out of it that he wasn't aware he was flying a plane with innocent people on board.  These emotions that steered him to lock out the pilot and deliberately kill everyone on board are different and in addition to his depression; extra, deadly elements there are no excuses for.
There is a difference between having an accident in a car when driving while depressed, and jamming a foot down on the gas pedal and aiming toward a school bus while ignoring screaming passengers.

There is a difference between major depression and bipolar disorder,  so it's at best highly misleading to say that "true biological depression is almost bipolar and thus accompanied by mania".    But depression does not lead to mass murder - so whatever was amiss with this pilot, it wasn't (just) depression.

The airlines cut costs because it brings more profit. Lufthansa has its lower priced unit, Germanwings, and as in the USA, where regional airlines hire less experienced pilots and pay them incredibly poorly, those fares are lower. Would you be willing to pay more for your ticket, either in the form of a higher fare or a surcharge? I would--but some people would take the risk, which is admittedly very small.

Personally, I think the suggestion for a fingerprint scanner to unlock the cockpit door is both sensible and a reasonable cost for airlines to assume. Let's hope it gets serious consideration.
